Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Diploma in Communication Skills
headline: Develop your soft skills by mastering the art of communication and persuasion, with this free online course.
description: This free online communication course will teach you the core skills of effective communication. You will be shown techniques to help improve your ability to listen, as well as how to improve your ability to speak considerately and politely. The importance of culture, context, and body language will also be discussed. This will be a great boost to both your personal and professional development. So, why wait? Start learning, today!
courseOutcomes: Discuss the difference between soft skills and hard skills
Differentiate between verbal and nonverbal communication
Explain the effect which new technologies have had upon communication
Discuss the importance of culture and context to communication
Discuss the difference between soft skills and hard skills
Differentiate between verbal and nonverbal communication
Explain the effect which new technologies have had upon communication
Discuss the importance of culture and context to communication
courseDescription:
This free course begins with the fundamentals of communication, such as communication channels, interpretation, and barriers to effective communication. You will also explore the basics of body language, and examine how context can influence how you communicate. You will also examine the crucial aspects of conversation such as listening, speaking and the importance of silence. 

You will then be shown techniques to help improve your ability to listen, as well as how to improve your ability to speak considerately and politely. The importance of culture, context, and body language will also be discussed. You will also explore the basics of visual and aural perception, and learn about how perception can impact your communicative relationships. The course will also cover important concepts of non-verbal communications such as space and gestures, and how to interpret facial expressions effectively. 

Finally, the course will focus on how communication styles can vary according to group dynamics and how to handle conflict. You will also be introduced you to the basics of persuasion and the role it plays in negotiation. These skills will be a great boost to both your personal and professional development. Start your next learning journey, today.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this diploma course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this diploma course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison diploma is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital diploma: a downloadable diploma in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked diploma, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked diploma in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All diploma are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison diploma, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison diploma, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our diploma pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module introduces you to communication in the context of soft skills. It draws on the main models of communication to identify the various components of the communication process and to understand potential barriers to achieving effective communication.
topics: Understanding The Communicative Environment  - Learning Outcomes
Understanding The Communicative Environment - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module explains the various components involved in the listening and speaking processes. It identifies barriers to effective listening and speaking based on culture, context and personal or environmental factors, and explains strategies for achieving effective inter-personal communication in socio-cultural environments.
topics: What to Listen For and Why

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module explores how we perceive the world through visuals and sounds. It examines the role of visual and aural perception in our understanding of meaning, and their relevance in the context of multimedia culture and new technologies.
topics: Visual And Aural Perception  - Learning Outcomes
The Aural: Its Relevance and Impact
Visual and Aural Perception - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module will guide you through body language as a vital components of nonverbal communication. It explores the role of culture, gender, social status and other factors in expressions of nonverbal communication, and examines facial expressions as a source of information about emotions.
topics: The Body and the Way it Communicates
The Face, Its Expressions, and What It Says

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Diploma in Communication Skills - First Assessment
modules.description: Assessment of modules 1, 2, 3, and 4 of free diploma course in communication skills: - Introduction to Communication. - Visual and Aural Perception. - Conversation. - Nonverbal Communication. You must score 80% or more to pass this assessment.
topics: Diploma in Communication Skills – First Assessment

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module explores the role of communication behaviour in building and maintaining positive relationships. It also examines different types of groups and the factors which affect group dynamics.

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module explores various types of conflicts and the role of verbal and nonverbal communication in conflict resolution. It also examines the significance of traditional and social networking.
topics: Social Network, Media and Extending Our Identity

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module explores the role of communication and relationships in the art of persuasion. It also discusses the effectiveness of different negotiator characteristics and negotiation techniques in reaching mutually satisfactory agreements between parties.
topics: The Art of Persuasion Part I
The Art of Persuasion Part II

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module explores the area of motivation – examining various theories on what drives people to achieve goals. It identifies strategies and techniques for improving motivation and examines the importance of motivational skills for effective leadership.

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Diploma in Communication Skills - Second Assessment
modules.description: Assessment of modules 6,7,8, and 9 of this free diploma course on Communication Skills: - Group Dynamics. - Conflicts And Networking. - Persuasion. - Motivation. You must score 80% or more to pass this assessment.
topics: Diploma in Communication Skills – Second Assessment

modules.name: Module
topics: Diploma in Communication Skills - Final Assessment

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Upon successful completion of this module students will be able to:
    • Discuss the difference between soft skills and hard skills.
    • Differentiate between covert and overt communication.
    • Identify different communication channels. 
    • Discuss filters and barriers.
    • Explain the effect which new technologies have had upon communication.
    • Differentiate between verbal and nonverbal communication.
    • Explain what is meant by a leakage in communication.
    • Explain why new technologies have made music and visuals more important. 
    • Discuss the importance of culture and context to communication.
  • This course consists of videos only.

    Any references to external resources, such as discussion boards and surveys, by the presenter are not a part of this free online course.

• Understanding the Communicative Environment I

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Understanding the Communicative Environment II

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Understanding the Communicative Environment II

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are:

    Skills
    Hard skills are easily quantifiable and measurable. 
    Soft skills are not easy to pin point and measure.
    Communication is considered a soft skill. 
    Overt communication is explicit.
    Covert communication is unintentional communication, such as someone who is angry trying not to show it and failing.

    Types of Communication
    Covert communication can also mean secret communication. 
    Communication is not simple; it is very complex. 
    There are many different channels of communication, such as voice, speech, text and body language. 
    Channels of communication can either be compatible or contradictory. 
    An example of compatible channels would be smiling when you are happy.
    An example of contradictory channels would be saying something polite while looking angry. 
    Ambiguity is when communication is not very clear.
    Interpretation is making sense of something which is communicated.
    Unless something is very definite there can be very different interpretations.

• Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are:

    The importance of listening
    Children need to listen to the language of the adults around them in order to communicate their needs and wants successfully.
    Listening is vital to intrapersonal communication, emotion, and support.
    According to worth the average person spends 45% of their communication time listening. 

    The difference between hearing and listening
    Research indicates that most people believe they are good listeners, however findings suggest that people use only about 25% of their listening capacity. 
    Hearing and listening is not the same thing, for example we hear but don’t listen of a lot of the background noise around us. 
    Every time you listen to something you are foregrounding that sound, you are actively concentrating on listening to that sound.  
    When you are listening, you can hear clichés, facts, thoughts, beliefs, feelings, and emotions.
    Repetitive or well know phrases are clichés.

    Barriers to effective listening
    Facts are the information that we are receiving from the other person.
    You are getting information on the other person’s attitudes and beliefs around specific issues. 
    The other person’s feelings and emotions are also transferred during communication. 
    We convert everything we hear into information and emotions. 
    Barriers to listening can be Linguistic, physical, or psychological. 
    A linguistic barrier is not understanding the language that is being spoken, or the way that the person is speaking the language.
    A physical barrier is being unable to listen due to an issue with your body such as being deaf, or having poor hearing.

    • Explain how the way we view things affects our perception.

• The World of Visual Culture

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• The World of Visual Culture

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Visual Perception

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Visual Perception

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• The Aural: Its Relevance and Impact

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• The Aural: Its Relevance and Impact

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are:

    Visual Culture and new technologies
    Visual culture has increased in importance with new technologies such as TVs, PCs, and screens. 
    Technology has been growing exponentially in the visual sphere.
    Modern life takes place on screen- our modern lives are mediated through screens.
    Reality is mediated by our senses, but modern technology has blocked our senses with a screen. This is experiencing reality second hand.
    Different cultures depend on different modes of communication, and today’s culture depends on visuals. This has an effect on how we communicate. 
    Limited space and screen size has resulted in the rise of text language, which has a lot of abbreviations. 

    The use of images in communication
    The existence of emoticons and images had raised the importance of images in today’s communication. 
    Mediation is anything that stands between an individual and reality. 
    The simulation of reality has become so advanced that it can cause you to question what is real and what isn’t.
    Avatars are characters which can interact with human beings. These monitors facial emotion and try and talk to the individual.
    The problem of simulacrum is when the simulation appears as reality, for example if a drawing appears lifelike. 
    Lightwave 8 creates images using sub-surface scattering techniques. 
    Visual culture is when we are submerged into visuals every day without realizing it.

• Lesson Summary

• The Face, Its Expressions, and What It Says

• The Face, Its Expressions, and What It Says

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are:

    Components of communication
    One study found that the percentage of components to communication are message (7%), Vocal (38%), and Nonverbal (55%).
    Context is relevant in changing how important each communication component is. 
    In face-to-face communication, the verbal component consists of about 35%, and the nonverbal component is around 65%.
    However, many studies overgeneralize and culture, learning, and behaviour are often not taken into account. 

    Culture and nonverbal communication
    There is debate over whether nonverbal communication is inborn or cultural. 
    Everyone uses body language either intuitively or conscientiously, but some are better than others at interpreting it. 
    Happiness, sadness, disgust, anger, fear, surprise, and scorn are all said to have been inborn rather than culturally taught. 
    However, culture can impact how we display these inborn emotions, for example in some cultures it is not ok for men to cry but it is ok for women to cry. 
    Gestures which communicate a specific meaning are known as emblems, for example putting your finger over your lips communicates silence. 
    However, the meaning of emblems can change or vary between cultures, for example the thumbs up symbol can mean ‘all ok’ or can mean superiority depending on the culture.
    Solitary gestures in isolation may be confusing, the context or cluster of symbols must also be considered. 
    Nonverbal communication can display power and social status much more effectively than verbal communication.

• Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are:

    Components of communication
    One study found that the percentage of components to communication are message (7%), Vocal (38%), and Nonverbal (55%).
    Context is relevant in changing how important each communication component is. 
    In face-to-face communication, the verbal component consists of about 35%, and the nonverbal component is around 65%.
    However, many studies overgeneralize and culture, learning, and behaviour are often not taken into account. 

    Culture and nonverbal communication
    There is debate over whether nonverbal communication is inborn or cultural. 
    Everyone uses body language either intuitively or conscientiously, but some are better than others at interpreting it. 
    Happiness, sadness, disgust, anger, fear, surprise, and scorn are all said to have been inborn rather than culturally taught. 
    However, culture can impact how we display these inborn emotions, for example in some cultures it is not ok for men to cry but it is ok for women to cry. 
    Gestures which communicate a specific meaning are known as emblems, for example putting your finger over your lips communicates silence. 
    However, the meaning of emblems can change or vary between cultures, for example the thumbs up symbol can mean ‘all ok’ or can mean superiority depending on the culture.
    Solitary gestures in isolation may be confusing, the context or cluster of symbols must also be considered. 
    Nonverbal communication can display power and social status much more effectively than verbal communication.
